elements.content: One of the emerging problems plaguing the chemical industry today is the efficient and cost-effective separation of C2 hydrocarbons. In order to help address this problem, we report a new material, NbU-1, constructed by extremely cheap starting materials. The special structural characteristics of NbU-1 such as the planar, mixed-valence copper clusters and Lewis-basic adsorption channels enforce interactions with acetylene molecules that lead to the highest kinetic separation efficiency for C2H2/C2H4. Via DFT-D calculations, it is indicated that C2H2 molecules are adsorbed onto the two adjacent Cu­(I) centers, but not the usual single open metal sites of Cu centers. The reported results not only provide information for a deep investigation into the separation mechanism but also offer an alternative strategy for preparing cost-effective materials that can perform highly efficient separations of light hydrocarbons.
elements.clean_text: One of the emerging problems plaguing the chemical industry today is the efficient and cost-effective separation of C2 hydrocarbons. In order to help address this problem, we report a new material, NbU-1, constructed by extremely cheap starting materials. The special structural characteristics of NbU-1 such as the planar, mixed-valence copper clusters and Lewis-basic adsorption channels enforce interactions with acetylene molecules that lead to the highest kinetic separation efficiency for C2H2/C2H4. Via DFT-D calculations, it is indicated that C2H2 molecules are adsorbed onto the two adjacent Cu(I) centers, but not the usual single open metal sites of Cu centers. The reported results not only provide information for a deep investigation into the separation mechanism but also offer an alternative strategy for preparing cost-effective materials that can perform highly efficient separations of light hydrocarbons.

elements.content: Purification of ethylene from C2 mixtures is an extremely important industrial process that plays a major role in the chemical and polymer industry. Due to the close boiling points and small differences between their condensabilities, cryogenic distillation is the current state-of-the-art process used for C2 separation, even though it is an extremely high energy-cost process. Inversely, nonthermally driven separations such as adsorption processes using porous materials have been receiving widespread attention from academia and industry over the last two decades.
elements.clean_text: Purification of ethylene from C2 mixtures is an extremely important industrial process that plays a major role in the chemical and polymer industry. Due to the close boiling points and small differences between their condensabilities, cryogenic distillation is the current state-of-the-art process used for C2 separation, even though it is an extremely high energy-cost process. Inversely, nonthermally driven separations such as adsorption processes using porous materials have been receiving widespread attention from academia and industry over the last two decades.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), which are renowned for their tunable porous structure and functional surfaces, have exhibited great potential as efficient separation materials. However, several fatal weaknesses still block the practical application of MOFs-based separation, such as the lack of effective interaction sites, low thermal or chemical stability, and the contradiction between the low separation efficiency and high cost of the starting materials. In order to surmount these defects, lots of research work has focused on increasing the effective open sites in MOF separation. For example, the MOF-74 series illustrated that the presence of an open metal within MOFs plays a critical role in the identification of similar C2 molecules. In response to this work, the pursuit of materials with additional open metal sites has become more intense as well as significantly more challenging. Due to the limitation of coordination habits, spatial hindrance, high cost of the starting materials, and synthesis process, the pursuit of larger high-nucleariry cluster-based MOFs has encountered a bottleneck, and the related research work still focused on several star MOF templates. In order to inject new vitality, highly efficient and cost-effective synthesis strategies and models are urgently required.
elements.clean_text: Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), which are renowned for their tunable porous structure and functional surfaces, have exhibited great potential as efficient separation materials. However, several fatal weaknesses still block the practical application of MOFs-based separation, such as the lack of effective interaction sites, low thermal or chemical stability, and the contradiction between the low separation efficiency and high cost of the starting materials. In order to surmount these defects, lots of research work has focused on increasing the effective open sites in MOF separation. For example, the MOF-74 series illustrated that the presence of an open metal within MOFs plays a critical role in the identification of similar C2 molecules. In response to this work, the pursuit of materials with additional open metal sites has become more intense as well as significantly more challenging. Due to the limitation of coordination habits, spatial hindrance, high cost of the starting materials, and synthesis process, the pursuit of larger high-nucleariry cluster-based MOFs has encountered a bottleneck, and the related research work still focused on several star MOF templates. In order to inject new vitality, highly efficient and cost-effective synthesis strategies and models are urgently required.

elements.content: Planar, high-nuclearity M–O based complexes have attracted increasing attention due to their fascinating properties. Each metal center in the planar core tends to generate two perpendicular open sites, which could be conjugated into two metal-active surfaces used to enhance the related properties of the planar complexes. With consideration of the complementarity and structural advantages, the material-integrated planar high-nuclearity node into MOFs could generate unprecedented separation performances, such as metal-active surfaces within pores that exert strong binding interactions with specific guest molecules. In order to validate the effectiveness of this constructive strategy, a novel MOF, (NH4)­{CuII 3·[CuIICuI 6(OH)6(Ad)6]2}·(H2O) x (NbU-1 = Ningbo University-1, Ad = adenine), has been directly constructed from cheap starting materials via one-step synthesis (see the ). NbU-1 exhibits not only high chemical stabilities but also the highest efficient kinetic selectivity of C2H2/C2H4.
elements.clean_text: Planar, high-nuclearity M-O based complexes have attracted increasing attention due to their fascinating properties. Each metal center in the planar core tends to generate two perpendicular open sites, which could be conjugated into two metal-active surfaces used to enhance the related properties of the planar complexes. With consideration of the complementarity and structural advantages, the material-integrated planar high-nuclearity node into MOFs could generate unprecedented separation performances, such as metal-active surfaces within pores that exert strong binding interactions with specific guest molecules. In order to validate the effectiveness of this constructive strategy, a novel MOF, (NH4){CuII 3⋅[CuIICuI 6(OH)6(Ad)6]2}⋅(H2O) x  (NbU-1 = Ningbo University-1, Ad = adenine), has been directly constructed from cheap starting materials via one-step synthesis (see the ). NbU-1 exhibits not only high chemical stabilities but also the highest efficient kinetic selectivity of C2H2/C2H4.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that NbU-1 presents a 3D porous structure based on heptanuclear Cu7(OH)6 clusters and single Cu ions linked by adenine ligands (). In the heptanuclear cluster, the central Cu1 ion and Cu2 ring are coplanar. Cu1 exhibits a distorted octahedral geometry with six μ3-OH– groups, which are distributed equally between the two sides of the heptanuclear plane. Cu2 atoms reside in a four-coordinated coordination mode with two μ3-OH– groups and two N donors from different adenine ligands. One Cu1 and two Cu2 atoms are bound together via one μ3-OH– group to form the Cu3(OH) triangle. Through sharing two isosceles edges, six triangles are fused into the heptanuclear planar, whose periphery is decorated by six adenine ligands that further separately coordinate with Cu3 atoms. Each Cu3 atom is surrounded by four adenine units via a N2 atom. For Cu1 and Cu3, the Cu–O and Cu–N distances fall in the range of the Cu­(II) state, but for Cu2, the related values indicate the Cu­(I) state (). Furthermore, the existence and proportion of two different copper states were also validated by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) (). The 2p3/2 peak is characterized by doublets with energies of 934.6 and 932.5 eV, corresponding to CuII and CuI, respectively. The integral areas of two peaks yield CuI:CuII in a ratio of 70:30, consistent with the crystallographic studies of 12CuI:5CuII.
elements.clean_text: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that NbU-1 presents a 3D porous structure based on heptanuclear Cu7(OH)6 clusters and single Cu ions linked by adenine ligands (). In the heptanuclear cluster, the central Cu1 ion and Cu2 ring are coplanar. Cu1 exhibits a distorted octahedral geometry with six μ3-OH- groups, which are distributed equally between the two sides of the heptanuclear plane. Cu2 atoms reside in a four-coordinated coordination mode with two μ3-OH- groups and two N donors from different adenine ligands. One Cu1 and two Cu2 atoms are bound together via one μ3-OH- group to form the Cu3(OH) triangle. Through sharing two isosceles edges, six triangles are fused into the heptanuclear planar, whose periphery is decorated by six adenine ligands that further separately coordinate with Cu3 atoms. Each Cu3 atom is surrounded by four adenine units via a N2 atom. For Cu1 and Cu3, the Cu-O and Cu-N distances fall in the range of the Cu(II) state, but for Cu2, the related values indicate the Cu(I) state (). Furthermore, the existence and proportion of two different copper states were also validated by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) (). The 2p3/2 peak is characterized by doublets with energies of 934.6 and 932.5 eV, corresponding to CuII and CuI, respectively. The integral areas of two peaks yield CuI:CuII in a ratio of 70:30, consistent with the crystallographic studies of 12CuI:5CuII.

elements.content: Perspective view of the six-connected heptanuclear Cu7(OH)6(Ad)6 planar and 4-connected single Cu (a, b); three-dimensional structure of NbU-1 composed of simplified nodes (c).
elements.clean_text: 1  Perspective view of the six-connected heptanuclear Cu7(OH)6(Ad)6 planar and 4-connected single Cu (a, b); three-dimensional structure of NbU-1 composed of simplified nodes (c).

elements.content: From a topological point of view, NbU-1 can be described as a (4,6)-connected 3D gar topological network () with the point (Schläfli) symbol {44·62}3{46·66·83}2. Meanwhile, the 3D framework presents an irregular void, featuring rich open channels and cavities (54.9% of the unit cell volume, ). The channels have trigonal windows, which are functionalized with Lewis-basic adsorption sites such as the uncoordinated pyridyl and amino groups of adenine on the inner surface. Furthermore, the surface of irregular pores is decorated with planar metal-binding sites created by heptanuclear clusters, which supply an exceptional number of open metal sites. Therefore, in terms of structural characteristics, the dual adsorption active sites of NbU-1 could synergistically enforce the specific host–guest interactions with C2H2.
elements.clean_text: From a topological point of view, NbU-1 can be described as a (4,6)-connected 3D gar topological network () with the point (Schläfli) symbol {44⋅62}3{46⋅66⋅83}2. Meanwhile, the 3D framework presents an irregular void, featuring rich open channels and cavities (54.9% of the unit cell volume, ). The channels have trigonal windows, which are functionalized with Lewis-basic adsorption sites such as the uncoordinated pyridyl and amino groups of adenine on the inner surface. Furthermore, the surface of irregular pores is decorated with planar metal-binding sites created by heptanuclear clusters, which supply an exceptional number of open metal sites. Therefore, in terms of structural characteristics, the dual adsorption active sites of NbU-1 could synergistically enforce the specific host-guest interactions with C2H2.

elements.content: Basic adsorption channel (a) and cavities (b) in the three-dimensional structure (c) of NbU-1.
elements.clean_text: 2  Basic adsorption channel (a) and cavities (b) in the three-dimensional structure (c) of NbU-1.

elements.content: Powder XRD studies displayed that NbU-1 not only possesses high thermal stability under the wet and vacuum conditions but also exhibits outstanding chemical stability in both boiling acidic and alkaline conditions even for 1 week, which means NbU-1 is more stable than most MOFs with exceptional gas separation performances. N2 adsorption of activated NbU-1 at 77 K shows a reversible type-I isotherm, giving a Langmuir surface area of 538.6 m2 g–1 (BET surface area of 368.2 m2 g–1). The Horvath–Kawazoe method shows a well uniform pore distribution of about 4 Å, indicating the ultramicroporous structure of NbU-1.
elements.clean_text: Powder XRD studies displayed that NbU-1 not only possesses high thermal stability under the wet and vacuum conditions but also exhibits outstanding chemical stability in both boiling acidic and alkaline conditions even for 1 week, which means NbU-1 is more stable than most MOFs with exceptional gas separation performances. N2 adsorption of activated NbU-1 at 77 K shows a reversible type-I isotherm, giving a Langmuir surface area of 538.6 m2 g-1 (BET surface area of 368.2 m2 g-1). The Horvath-Kawazoe method shows a well uniform pore distribution of about 4 Å, indicating the ultramicroporous structure of NbU-1.

elements.content: The stable, ultramicroporous structure and functionalized porous surface prompted us to further examine the capacities of NbU-1 for the adsorption of small C2 hydrocarbons. Single-component adsorption isotherms for C2 hydrocarbons were measured at 273 and 298 K, respectively, which shows NbU-1 exhibits adsorption capacities with the trend of C2H2 ≫ C2H4 ≈ C2H6, and the C2H2/C2H4 and C2H2/C2H6 uptake ratios of NbU-1 were estimated to be 1.76 and 1.69 at 273 K, which is notably larger than the values for the MOF-74 series separation, with a value range of 1.21–1.36. According to the virial equation (c), the heat of adsorption values at zero loading for C2H2, C2H4, and C2H6 are 38.3, 37.9, and 32.2 kJ mol–1, respectively. Therefore, the remarkable adsorption enthalpies, which have a trend of C2H2 ≈ C2H4 > C2H6, must be attributed to the specific structural characteristics of the Lewis-basic sites and the planar metal-binding sites. Simultaneously, the similar adsorption enthalpies for C2H2 and C2H4 manifest that NbU-1 might not be suitable for thermodynamic separation of C2H2/C2H4.
elements.clean_text: The stable, ultramicroporous structure and functionalized porous surface prompted us to further examine the capacities of NbU-1 for the adsorption of small C2 hydrocarbons. Single-component adsorption isotherms for C2 hydrocarbons were measured at 273 and 298 K, respectively, which shows NbU-1 exhibits adsorption capacities with the trend of C2H2 ≫ C2H4 ~ C2H6, and the C2H2/C2H4 and C2H2/C2H6 uptake ratios of NbU-1 were estimated to be 1.76 and 1.69 at 273 K, which is notably larger than the values for the MOF-74 series separation, with a value range of 1.21-1.36. According to the virial equation (c), the heat of adsorption values at zero loading for C2H2, C2H4, and C2H6 are 38.3, 37.9, and 32.2 kJ mol-1, respectively. Therefore, the remarkable adsorption enthalpies, which have a trend of C2H2 ~ C2H4 > C2H6, must be attributed to the specific structural characteristics of the Lewis-basic sites and the planar metal-binding sites. Simultaneously, the similar adsorption enthalpies for C2H2 and C2H4 manifest that NbU-1 might not be suitable for thermodynamic separation of C2H2/C2H4.

elements.content: (a) C2H x sorption isotherms for NbU-1 at 273 and 298 K. (b) Isotherms of the relationship between the adsorption amount and the equilibrium time. (c) C2H x isosteric heats of adsorption for NbU-1. (d) IAST adsorption selectivities for NbU-1 of equimolar C2H2 /C2H x mixtures.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) C2H x  sorption isotherms for NbU-1 at 273 and 298 K. (b) Isotherms of the relationship between the adsorption amount and the equilibrium time. (c) C2H x  isosteric heats of adsorption for NbU-1. (d) IAST adsorption selectivities for NbU-1 of equimolar C2H2 /C2H x  mixtures.

elements.content: Due to this, kinetic adsorption behavior was carefully studied because gas separation is the process of nonequilibrium adsorption, which is related not only to the interactions between the host and the guest but also to the kinetic diffusion rate of the gas molecules themselves within the material. The relationship between the adsorption amount and equilibrium time gives a time sequence of T(C2H2) ≪ T(C2H6) < T(C2H4) (especially the lower adsorption amounts at 0–0.5 bar) (b). The shortest equilibrium time not only indicate the fastest diffusion rate within NbU-1 for C2H2 but also theoretically endow NbU-1 with the separation potential of C2H2 based on a combination of kinetic diffusion rates and enthalpies of adsorption.
elements.clean_text: Due to this, kinetic adsorption behavior was carefully studied because gas separation is the process of nonequilibrium adsorption, which is related not only to the interactions between the host and the guest but also to the kinetic diffusion rate of the gas molecules themselves within the material. The relationship between the adsorption amount and equilibrium time gives a time sequence of T(C2H2) ≪ T(C2H6) < T(C2H4) (especially the lower adsorption amounts at 0-0.5 bar) (b). The shortest equilibrium time not only indicate the fastest diffusion rate within NbU-1 for C2H2 but also theoretically endow NbU-1 with the separation potential of C2H2 based on a combination of kinetic diffusion rates and enthalpies of adsorption.

elements.content: In order to evaluate the real gas separation abilities of NbU-1, ideal adsorbed solution theory (IAST) was performed on 50–50 C2H2/C2H4 and C2H2/C2H6 binary mixtures, which yield separation selectivity values for NbU-1 of C2H2/C2H4 and C2H2/C2H6 under 100 KPa of 12.1 and 12.5 at 273 K and 5.9 and 6.5 at 298 K, respectively (d). The relatively high selectivity value of C2H2/C2H4 for NbU-1 is greater than that of the presented star MOFs (), illustrating the great potential of NbU-1 as an efficient separation material for C2H2/C2H4. Prompted by the results of theoretical calculations, experimental breakthrough studies were further performed for the C2H2/C2H4 mixtures that were flowed over a packed bed of activated NbU-1 at 293 K and 1 bar. Two different ratios of C2H2/C2H4 mixture (50:50 and 1:99, v/v) were used, and clear separations curves were realized (). It was found that NbU-1 displays a remarkable separation of the 1:99 mixtures, where the breakthrough of C2H2 occurs at 93 min after dosing the gas mixture. Furthermore, an extremely high purity of C2H4 that was greater than 99.997% was obtained (the detection limit of the GC is 0.003%). Moreover, based on the breakthrough curve, the amounts of C2H2 adsorbed by NbU-1 during the time 0 ∼ t break can be calculated as 1.2 and 27.6 cm3 g–1 from 1/99 and 50/50 C2H2/C2H4 mixtures, respectively, which are 13.2% and 52.0% of the values obtained from the single-component adsorption isotherms (9.1 and 53.1 cm3 g–1 at T = 298 K, P C2H2 = 0.01 and 0.5 bar). Compared to the performance of other MOF-based separation materials (), it is worth noting that NbU-1 exhibits the longest dimensionless breakthrough time (τbreak) of C2H2 for the 50/50 mixtures with a specific constant flow rate of 2 mL/min, and for the 1/99 mixtures, the τbreak of C2H2 is only lower than UTSA-200a and illustrates the excellent kinetic factors; especially the fastest diffusion rate of C2H2 and excellent stability promoted NbU-1 to be an extremely practical material for C2H2/C2H4 separations. There is no obvious enhancement of the separation of acetylene/ethane compared to acetylene/ethylene. For ethylene/ethane, there is no separation effect for NbU-1, which was also caused by the faster diffusion rate of ethane than ethylene ().
elements.clean_text: In order to evaluate the real gas separation abilities of NbU-1, ideal adsorbed solution theory (IAST) was performed on 50-50 C2H2/C2H4 and C2H2/C2H6 binary mixtures, which yield separation selectivity values for NbU-1 of C2H2/C2H4 and C2H2/C2H6 under 100 KPa of 12.1 and 12.5 at 273 K and 5.9 and 6.5 at 298 K, respectively (d). The relatively high selectivity value of C2H2/C2H4 for NbU-1 is greater than that of the presented star MOFs (), illustrating the great potential of NbU-1 as an efficient separation material for C2H2/C2H4. Prompted by the results of theoretical calculations, experimental breakthrough studies were further performed for the C2H2/C2H4 mixtures that were flowed over a packed bed of activated NbU-1 at 293 K and 1 bar. Two different ratios of C2H2/C2H4 mixture (50:50 and 1:99, v/v) were used, and clear separations curves were realized (). It was found that NbU-1 displays a remarkable separation of the 1:99 mixtures, where the breakthrough of C2H2 occurs at 93 min after dosing the gas mixture. Furthermore, an extremely high purity of C2H4 that was greater than 99.997% was obtained (the detection limit of the GC is 0.003%). Moreover, based on the breakthrough curve, the amounts of C2H2 adsorbed by NbU-1 during the time 0 ~ t break can be calculated as 1.2 and 27.6 cm3 g-1 from 1/99 and 50/50 C2H2/C2H4 mixtures, respectively, which are 13.2% and 52.0% of the values obtained from the single-component adsorption isotherms (9.1 and 53.1 cm3 g-1 at T = 298 K, P C2H2  = 0.01 and 0.5 bar). Compared to the performance of other MOF-based separation materials (), it is worth noting that NbU-1 exhibits the longest dimensionless breakthrough time (τbreak) of C2H2 for the 50/50 mixtures with a specific constant flow rate of 2 mL/min, and for the 1/99 mixtures, the τbreak of C2H2 is only lower than UTSA-200a and illustrates the excellent kinetic factors; especially the fastest diffusion rate of C2H2 and excellent stability promoted NbU-1 to be an extremely practical material for C2H2/C2H4 separations. There is no obvious enhancement of the separation of acetylene/ethane compared to acetylene/ethylene. For ethylene/ethane, there is no separation effect for NbU-1, which was also caused by the faster diffusion rate of ethane than ethylene ().

elements.content: Breakthrough curves for C2H2/C2H4 separations (50/50) (a) and (1/99) (b).
elements.clean_text: 4  Breakthrough curves for C2H2/C2H4 separations (50/50) (a) and (1/99) (b).

elements.content: Additionally, spin-polarized density functional theory calculations were carried out to investigate the role of planar metal-binding sites in NbU-1. The extended NbU-1 can be simplified as the effective moiety of Cu7(OH)6(Ad)6 to highlight the crucial role of the planar metal-binding sites in the process of separation. Different from the normal adsorption mechanism, in NbU-1, the series of C2 molecules prefer to bind onto the open metal sites via dangling bonds between the d-block-electron-rich regions of two adjacent CuI atoms (, ). Furthermore, the adsorption energy has been calculated as −13.07 kcal/mol for C2H2, −12.57 kcal/mol for C2H4, and −12.01 kcal/mol for C2H6, meaning the weak adsorption of these C2 molecules onto a metal-active surface. The average C–Cu bond lengths of 2.922 Å for C2H2, 3.113 Å for C2H4, and 3.483 Å for C2H6 indicate the important role of the weak van der Waals force between gas molecules and planar unit. The different bond characteristic of C2 molecules must be responsible for the origination of different weak C–Cu interactions. Observed from a theoretical investigation, the planar, open metal sites of the four-coordinated CuI atoms, especially through conjugation with each other, play an important role in the selective adsorption of different C2 light hydrocarbons.
elements.clean_text: Additionally, spin-polarized density functional theory calculations were carried out to investigate the role of planar metal-binding sites in NbU-1. The extended NbU-1 can be simplified as the effective moiety of Cu7(OH)6(Ad)6 to highlight the crucial role of the planar metal-binding sites in the process of separation. Different from the normal adsorption mechanism, in NbU-1, the series of C2 molecules prefer to bind onto the open metal sites via dangling bonds between the d-block-electron-rich regions of two adjacent CuI atoms (, ). Furthermore, the adsorption energy has been calculated as -13.07 kcal/mol for C2H2, -12.57 kcal/mol for C2H4, and -12.01 kcal/mol for C2H6, meaning the weak adsorption of these C2 molecules onto a metal-active surface. The average C-Cu bond lengths of 2.922 Å for C2H2, 3.113 Å for C2H4, and 3.483 Å for C2H6 indicate the important role of the weak van der Waals force between gas molecules and planar unit. The different bond characteristic of C2 molecules must be responsible for the origination of different weak C-Cu interactions. Observed from a theoretical investigation, the planar, open metal sites of the four-coordinated CuI atoms, especially through conjugation with each other, play an important role in the selective adsorption of different C2 light hydrocarbons.

elements.content: DFT-D-calculated C2H2, C2H4, and C2H6 adsorption binding sites on the Cu7(OH)6(adenine)6 unit.
elements.clean_text: 5  DFT-D-calculated C2H2, C2H4, and C2H6 adsorption binding sites on the Cu7(OH)6(adenine)6 unit.

elements.content: In conclusion, NbU-1 exhibits several advantages as the multiple CuI open metal-binding sites, extreme chemical stability and the best price-performance ratio () compared to the reported MOF-based separations. Via breakthrough experiments, NbU-1 clearly illustrates the excellent kinetic parameters for the separation of C2H2/C2H4 mixtures. The outstanding and record-breaking separation abilities of NbU-1 are ascribed to the abundant basic adsorption sites and special planar, open metal-binding sites. Therefore, the related research results illustrate an important and significant advancement in the design and preparation of MOF materials for practical C2 separations and can provide a model for further MOF development.
elements.clean_text: In conclusion, NbU-1 exhibits several advantages as the multiple CuI open metal-binding sites, extreme chemical stability and the best price-performance ratio () compared to the reported MOF-based separations. Via breakthrough experiments, NbU-1 clearly illustrates the excellent kinetic parameters for the separation of C2H2/C2H4 mixtures. The outstanding and record-breaking separation abilities of NbU-1 are ascribed to the abundant basic adsorption sites and special planar, open metal-binding sites. Therefore, the related research results illustrate an important and significant advancement in the design and preparation of MOF materials for practical C2 separations and can provide a model for further MOF development.

metadata.title:
